item.title: Resources
item.description:
If you have suggestions or queries, don’t be a stranger.

Where to present research on robust machine learning, healthcare, fairness

  • Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS)
  • International Conference for Machine Learning (ICML)
  • ACM Conference on Health, Inference, and Learning (CHIL)
  • Fair ML for Health Workshop at NeurIPS
  • Machine Learning for Health (ML4H) Workshop at NeurIPS

Representative Machine Learning

  • Women in Machine Learning
  • Black in AI
  • Queer in AI
  • LatinX in AI
  • (Dis)Ability in AI

Introductory guides

  • Causal Inference textbook – by Miguel Hernan and Jamie Robins
  • History of Fairness in ML – by Ben Hutchinson and Margaret Mitchell
  • ML for Healthcare class at MIT – by course staff including myself

Advice for aspiring and current ML researchers

  • Applications for computer science PhD – by Jean Yang (@jeanqasaur)
  • Emailing professors – by Dan Roy (@roydanroy)
  • Interviewing for PhD programs – by Nils Gehlenborg (@ngehlenborg)
  • MIT reporting procedures for sexual misconduct, intimate partner violence, or stalking
  • What should grad students be learning? – by Michael Mitzenmacher
  • Expectations for advisors and students – by John Regehr (@johnregehr), Suresh Venkatasubramanian (@geomblog), and Matt Might (@mattmight)
  • Handling math bullies – by Fan Chung Graham
  • Combatting Anti-Blackness in the AI Community – by Devin Guillory (@databoydg)
  • Paper writing tips – by Jacob Steinhardt
  • Shortening papers – by Devi Parikh (@deviparikh)
  • Responding to peer feedback – by Matt Might (@mattmight)
  • Writing conference rebuttals – by Devi Parikh (@deviparikh), Dhruv Batra (@DhruvBatraDB), Stefan Lee (@stefmlee)
  • Reviewing conference papers – by Colin Raffel (@colinraffel)
  • How to write a good conference review – CVPR 2020 Tutorial
  • Academic job search in 10 questions – by Elissa Redmiles (@eredmil1) and Nicolas Papernot (@NicolasPapernot)
  • Another academic job search guide – by Westley Weimer
  • How to reject a candidate – by Sara Davis (@PsySciSar)

item.title: Reading List
item.description:
I like to share what I’m reading to keep me motivated. For academic papers, see my papers repo, which is probably outdated. Below are books I’ve read.

Books I’ve especially loved are marked with an asterik.

2020

  1. Trick Mirror, Jia Tolentino*
  2. I Like to Watch, Emily Nussbaum
  3. Children of Virtue and Vengence, Tomi Adeyemi
  4. The Farm, Joanne Ramos*
  5. Useful Phrases for Immigrants, May-lee Chai
  6. Uncanny Valley, Anna Wiener*
  7. Exit West, Mohsin Hamid*
  8. I’ve Got Your Number, Sophie Kinsella
  9. Remember Me?, Sophie Kinsella*
  10. Little Fires Everywhere, Celeste Ng*
  11. The Art of Gathering, Priya Parker*
  12. My Year of Rest and Relaxation, Ottessa Moshfegh
  13. All the Names They Used for God, Anjali Sachdeva
  14. Station Eleven, Emily St. John Mandel
  15. Severance, Ling Ma*
  16. Dear Life, Alice Munro
  17. Where the Crawdads Sing, Delia Owens
  18. My Not So Perfect Life, Sophie Kinsella*
  19. The Canterville Ghost, Oscar Wilde*
  20. Dear Girls, Ali Wong*
  21. Pachinko, Min Jin Lee*
  22. The Underground Railroad, Colson Whitehead*
  23. The Biggest Bluff, Maria Konnikova
  24. Big Friendship, Aminatou Sow and Ann Friedman*
  25. Recursion, Blake Crouch
  26. Till We Have Faces, C. S. Lewis
  27. The Vanishing Half, Brit Bennett*
  28. Nothing to See Here, Kevin Wilson
  29. Big Summer, Jennifer Weiner
  30. The Guest List, Lucy Foley

2019

  1. Conversations with Friends, Sally Rooney
  2. Three Body Problem, Cixin Liu*
  3. Text Me When You Get Home, Kayleen Schaefer
  4. Winners Take All, Anand Giridharadas
  5. Man’s Search for Meaning, Viktor Frankl*
  6. The Heart, Maylis de Kerangal*
  7. Less, Andrew Greer
  8. Midnight’s Children, Salman Rushdie*
  9. The Idiot, Elif Batuman*
  10. Heartburn, Nora Ephron*
  11. Little Women, Louisa May Alcott*
  12. The Red Book, Deborah Copaken Kogan*
  13. What I Talk About When I Talk about Running, Haruki Murakami*
  14. The Boy Who Was Raised as a Dog, Bruce Perry and Maia Szalavitz*
  15. Normal People, Sally Rooney*
  16. Milk and Honey, Rupi Kaur
  17. Undomestic Goddess, Sophie Kinsella
  18. Can You Keep A Secret?, Sophie Kinsella*
  19. Love in the Time of Cholera, Gabriel Garcia-Marquez
  20. Maybe You Should Talk to Someone, Lori Gottlieb*
  21. The Privileged Poor, Anthony Abraham Jack
  22. How to Change Your Mind, Michael Pollan
  23. Murder on the Orient Express, Agatha Christie*
  24. Men Without Women, Haruki Murakami
  25. The Most Fun We Ever Had, Claire Lombardo*
  26. Chemistry, Weike Wang*
  27. The Testaments, Margaret Atwood*
  28. What Alice Forgot, Liane Moriarty
  29. Exhalation, Ted Chiang*
  30. Invisible Women, Caroline Criado Perez*

2018

  1. Everything I Never Told You, Celeste Ng*
  2. Neon in Daylight, Hermione Hoby
  3. I’ll be Gone in the Dark, Michelle McNamara
  4. Sourdough, Robin Sloan
  5. Surprise Me, Sophie Kinsella
  6. Eligible, Curtis Sittenfeld
  7. The Power, Naomi Alderman*
  8. Just the Funny Parts, Nell Scovell*
  9. The Immortalists, Chloe Benjamin
  10. Bad Blood, John Carreyrou*
  11. Her Body and Other Parties, Carmen Maria Machado*
  12. Crazy Rich Asians, Kevin Kwan
  13. How to Talk So Kids Will Listen & Listen So Kids Will Talk, Adele Faber and Elaine Mazlish*
  14. Factfulness, Hans Rosling, Anna Rosling Ronnlund, and Ola Rosling
  15. Everything Happens for a Reason and Other Lies I’ve Loved, Kate Bowler
  16. I, Robot, Isaac Asimov
  17. Circe, Madeline Miller*
  18. The Silence of the Girls, Pat Barker
  19. Siblings Without Rivalry, Adele Faber and Ealine Mazlish*
  20. Who Gets What – and Why, Alvin E. Roth
  21. Private Citizens, Tony Tulathimutte
  22. Dept. of Sepculation, Jenny Offill*
  23. Am I There Yet?, Mari Andrew
  24. A Life of Adventure and Delight, Akhil Sharma
  25. Children of Blood and Bone, Tomi Adeyemi
  26. Asymmetry, Lisa Hallisday*

item.title: Talks
item.description:
Here are the slides from my presentations. When similar talks are given, only one representative slide deck will be posted.

Robust Machine Learning

  • Robustly Extracting Medical Knowledge from Electronic Health Records, UMass Lowell, October 2019.
  • Causal Inference Case Studies, MIT 6.S897/HST.956 Recitation, April 2019.
  • Clinical Reinforcement Learning, MIT 6.S897/HST.956 Recitation, April 2019.
  • Robust Machine Learning for Healthcare, CSAIL - Microsoft Research Trustworthy and Robust AI Initiative, February 2019.

Ethics and Fairness

  • Fixing Disparities in Health with Machine Learning, Data and Society, October 2019.
  • Fairness, Ethics, and Bias in Healthcare, University of Toronto Guest Lecture, January 2019.
  • Why is My Classifier Discriminatory?, NeurIPS Spotlight Paper, December 2018.

Introductory Materials

  • Machine Learning for Healthcare Professionals, DiME Society Webinar, September 2019.

item.title: Bio
item.description:
Irene Chen

She is a ML researcher.
